column1: Catalina Foothills is a census-designated place (CDP) located north of Tucson in Pima County
column3: United States.  Situated in the southern foothills of the Santa Catalina Mountains
column4: Catalina Foothills had a population of 50
column5: 796 at the 2010 census.  Catalina Foothills is one of the most affluent communities in Arizona and in the U.S.
column6: with the 6th highest per capita income in Arizona
column7: and the 14th highest per capita income in the U.S. of communities with a population of at least 50
column8: 000.  The Catalina Foothills community includes some of Arizona's most expensive homes and land
column9: and has the highest median property value. It also includes resorts

column1: The history of the modern development of the Catalina Foothills dates back to the early 1920s.  Prior to that time
column2: the Catalina Foothills area was primarily federal trust land and open range for cattle grazing.  Beginning in the 1920s
column3: John Murphey began purchasing property north of River Road in the foothills of the Santa Catalina Mountains.Murphey originally planned to develop 10 housing subdivisions with large lots.  Murphey's vision for the Catalina Foothills community was low-density residential development
column4: on lots designed for maximum privacy
column7: and mountain views.  In 1928 Murphey bought a 7
column8: 000 acres (28 km2) tract of land north of River Road between North Oracle Road and Sabino Canyon in a federal land auction.Around the same time
column11: was retained to implement John Murphey's vision.  Residential development in the Catalina Foothills began in the 1930s
column12: and Joesler designed a number of the homes.

column2: residents of the Foothills organized the Catalina Foothills School District to serve the local school-aged population.  Murphey sold the school district the land for the first school building near East River Road and North Campbell Avenue
column3: and Joesler designed the first school building.  This building continues to house the school district's administration.

column2: Joesler and Murphey completed the building of St. Philip's in the Hills Episcopal Church at the corner of Campbell Avenue and River Road
column3: which was then the main entrance to the Catalina Foothills Estates
column4: an example of Spanish Colonial Mission architecture.  The land for the church was donated by Murphey
column5: and Joesler donated his services for its design. The congregation paid only for construction.

column1: The Catalina Foothills’ population continued to expand
column2: as development continued northward on the Oracle Road corridor
column3: and eastward along the Ina Road/Skyline Drive corridor.  In 1963
column4: the Skyline Country Club was established.  In the 1980s
column5: both La Paloma Resort and Ventana Canyon Resort were established.

column1: Catalina Foothills is served by three public school districts:
Amphitheater Public Schools serves neighborhoods in the western Catalina Foothills
column3: Cobblestone Estates
column4: and the Via Entrada neighborhood.  Amphi schools serving the Catalina Foothills perform among the top in the state academically
column5: and include Canyon del Oro High School.  In 2007 and again in 2010
column6: Newsweek Magazine rated Canyon del Oro in the top 5% of public schools in the U.S.
column7: one of a handful of schools in Arizona included on the list.

column1: Catalina Foothills School District serves the upper Catalina Foothills
column2: with schools that score among the highest in the state on standardized tests
column3: including Catalina Foothills High School.  Catalina Foothills High School is the only high school located in Catalina Foothills proper
column5: Catalina Foothills had Arizona's second highest percentage of students exceeding math
column6: the third highest percentage of students exceeding reading standards
column7: and the ninth highest percentage of student exceeding writing standards on the Arizona Instrument to Measure Success (AIMS) mandatory exam.

column1: Tucson Unified School District serves the lower and northeastern neighborhoods of the Catalina Foothills.  TUSD schools that serve the Catalina Foothills are Jacob C. Fruchtendler Elementary School

column1: Popular attractions for residents and visitors in the Santa Catalina Mountains include:
Ventana CanyonThe Catalina Foothills is also home to La Encantada

column1: The Catalina Foothills community also forms the core of Tucson's resort corridor.  These include the Hacienda del Sol Resort
column3: Loews Ventana Canyon Resort

column1: The Foothills area is also home to the DeGrazia Gallery in the Sun near the intersection of North Swan Road and East Skyline Drive. Built by artist Ted DeGrazia starting in 1951
column3: 000 m2) property is listed on the National Register of Historic Places and features an eclectic chapel

column1: The Catalina Foothills also boasts one of the most unusual subdivisions in Tucson
column2: called Sin Vacas (Without Cows). According to historian David Leighton
column3: in an article published on April 8
column5: in the Arizona Daily Star newspaper
column6: the land where Sin Vacas subdivision now sits was owned at one point by steel magnate William J. “Jack” Holliday who was fond of desert wildlife and fenced in his property to keep cows out
column7: and  called it Rancho Sin Vacas (Ranch Without Cows).  Developer Kelley Rollings later came along and purchased the land and along with his Spanish speaking office manager named some of the most interesting street names in Tucson
column8: giving many of them names related to the Seven Deadly Sins
column9: such as Calle Sin Pecado (Street Without Sin) and Plaza Sin Lujuria (Place Without Lust).

column1: The Tucson Arizona Temple of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints is located in Catalina Foothills
column2: near the intersection of Ina Road and Skyline Drive. It was completed in June 2017 and dedicated later that year in August.
